title: Prusa i3 MK2 YI Camera holder

description.text:
Hello !
I started with this great idea and thing : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1704137
It was already reworked (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2010233) but I had some small remarks on the design (and solutions) :
-the screw was too long and the tread was too small : very hard to put the nut on if you print it fast (0.2) : smaller length and usage of a Trapezoidal ISO thread form, step 1.5.
-the screw could rotate in its placement on the holder : creation of a square head screw
-the nut was not easy to screw : redesign with bigger ears
-the slider was too thin and flexible : a bit thicker to allow infill on the sliding part
-the holder was a little tight : dimensions slightly enlarged

I used PLA for holder, screw and nut, and ABS for the slider to resist on ABS prints.

The first timelapse test result is below on the video

No

Fusion 360

title: Charles and NiXie's Hamster House on the Moon

description.text:
From the book LEO the Maker Prince:
http://www.leothemakerprince.com
http://www.amazon.com/LEO-Maker-Prince-Journeys-Printing/dp/1457183145
This is the modular hamster house system that Charles made for his hamster, Weenie. Capsules can be rearranged and attached in different configurations, end-to-end or stacked. PLEASE NOTE: the clear parts pictured here were created using the i.materialise service and may be impossible to replicate with a desktop 3D printer.

This is a modular system to house a small dwarf hamster (not the large Syrian variety). Capsules can be rearranged and attached in different configurations, end-to-end or stacked. The twist ring and closed rings twist and lock at the ends of the capsule bands to hold each one together. The main part of the model is the modular capsule. Here, two capsules are stacked and connected together, with a bend tube channel for the hamster to explore. NOTE! VERY IMPORTANT!
This is by far the most complex of the LEO series of objects, and most of the parts you see here were created and polished by a professional 3D printing service, not an at-home printer. In particular, the clear parts such as the capsule, the water bottle and the bend tube may be impossible to recreate at home. it's a good idea to have them clear so you can see your pet! For two capsules as pictured, here are instructions:

  • Print the following in white:
    hamster_house_band_X4.stl (4 pieces)
    hamster_closed_twist_cap_X2.stl (2 pieces)
    hamster_twist_ring_X2.stl (2 pieces)
    hamster_press_fit_cap_X2.stl (2 pieces)

  • Print the following in clear and polish to get them as transparent as possible:
    capsule_holes_left.stl (2 pieces)
    capsule_holes_right.stl (2 pieces)
    hamster_bend_tube_left.stl (1 piece)
    hamster_bend_tube_right.stl (1 piece)
    ladder_tube.stl (1 piece)

  • Assemble the capsules by placing a left and right capsules together. They will be oriented with the small ventilation holes at the top. You should see a large hole at the top, and one on the bottom.

  • Place each capsule inside a set of two bands, so the capsule edges sit inside the channels on the inside of the band. Be sure to align the large holes at the top and bottom of the capsules with the holes on the bands.

  • Use the ladder tube as a press fit to mate the two capsule assemblies together and give the hamster a way to climb up.

  • Place the closed end caps on one end of the capsules and press and turn to lock into place.

  • Place the twist rings on the other end of the capsules.

  • Put the left and right of the bend tube together and insert it into the open ends of the two stacked capsules. Twist the rings to lock the assembly in place.

  • Use a press fit cap to plug the large hole at the bottom of the lower capsule.

  • For the water bottle, print the hamster_water_bottle.stl file and the hamster_water_bottle_top.stl file. The top should have a pinhole in it to allow the water to drip through. The water bottle will likely need to be split and then glued together in order to clear support and have a proper hollow cavity.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/7zlh77A74zY

This thing is a method for making ACME flange nuts with perfect threads. It starts with a flange nut that is printed in two halves. The pieces are then put into a vice and clamped on the flat edges. Using a solder rework gun, the leadscrew is heated and the threads are formed.  
See instructions for more info.

This part is designed for 3/8" ACME screws. The process of making the threads and joining the part goes as follows:
  • Print the parts in PLA with 100% infill
  • Clamp the parts lightly onto the leadscrew using a vice. The halves of the flange nut will not clamp down all the way since the plastic must be reformed into threads.
  • Heat the leadscrew with a solder rework at high temperature until the PLA softens. Carefully apply more pressure with the vice so that the threads are pushed in. Do not heat the PLA directly. You want the leadscrew to be hot, but not the plastic.
  • Once sufficient threads have been formed, wait for the piece to cool. Now unclamp the whole assembly. The halves will separate and you will be able to inspect the depth of the threads. Put the leadscrew in water to cool it back down to room temp.
  • Place everything back in the vice. Using the solder rework gun, set the temperature to ~210-230C. Get a piece of PLA filament to use as welding material. Melt the PLA with the heat gun and spread the melted plastic using a flat head screwdriver. Only weld ONE of the seams.
  • This part is critical. Take everything out of the vice. You should be able to separate the seams just enough that the nut moves easily on the leadscrew. Set the gap exactly how you want it and weld the final seam.
    • In the pictures, I have used black PLA as the welding material so that you can see what I am doing. This method is not perfect just yet as I have gotten some warping of the flange due to heating the PLA. With a little more effort I think I can make some very functional parts!

The Card Reader Bracket by HPonstein was the inspiration. This prevents having to always reach down the side of the printer to insert your micro SD card. I made this to fit a full size SDcard instead of the microSD at a user's request. Make sure the flexible cable for your SDcard extension is a minimum of 25CM if you elect to mount this on the left side (specific to the Anet A6).

My print didn't include any supports. I wonder if using the slicer's support would have prevented warping. Not too shabby considering no support and a 24 degree incline. Consider using supports for better results and hopefully less warping.

NOT compatible with the round fan shroud! However the Mistral 2.1 works perfectly.

Made a stabalizer for the Tronxy P802 z-Axis. You can use any 608 bearing you want. The fit is 0,3mm wider, so it should be easy to assemble.
I would recommend using sealed bearings instead of the shown shielded. http://www.banggood.com/10pcs-8x22x7mm-Deep-Groove-Miniature-Bearing-Sealing-608-2RS-608RS-Deep-Groove-Ball-Bearing-p-1052876.html?p=IV1908725094201408TX

http://www.gearbest.com/novelty-toys/pp_615865.html?wid=21&lkid=10619597

Update V2: More stable due to inner 45° angle. Cut outs for the outer screws. (on the wrong side...), spacers to fit the longer screws provided with the printer

Update V3: Proper cut outs (chamfer) for the outer screws. Raised the spacers for the screws a bit. Chamfers for easier insert of the bearing and rod.

Assembly instruction:

  1. Move your z-axis to the top. Remove the lead screw, the rod, the motor and coupler.
  2. Insert all screws in the holder, the bearing, the coupler of the stepper motor and place it on the mount.
  3. Insert the rod to go trough the acrylic frame and tighten the screws a bit to the motor, so the whole assembly can still move.
  4. Mount the coupler to the top, touching the bearing and insert the lead screw
  5. Make sure everything works without any tension on the rod or lead screw. The coupler can be slightly bend. Thats the reason we are using a spring coupler and then tension all the screws.

If sbd needs different dimensions just write me.

Dimensions:
Distance leadscrew - rod: 17mm
Distance screw holes: 31mm
Tolerances: 0,3mm

description.text:
A couple of printed parts to convert the not-so-great-but-really-cheap Lantian LT-130 frame ( http://www.banggood.com/de/Liantian-LT130-ZMR130-QAV130-130MM-Carbon-Fiber-Frame-Kit-for-Mini-Racer-Helocopter-Multicopter-p-1025924.html ) into a nifty fpv mini for garden flying. Uses a AC-401 receiver, though other micro receiver should work as well. The camera is a 1/4" CMOS: http://www.banggood.com/600TVL-100-Degree-14-Cmos-2_8mm-Lens-FPV-Camera-PALNTSC-3_3-5V-p-1092326.html?rmmds=search. Battery goes under the belly which keeps everything nicely balanced. And it's so light that you won't damage the battery in a crash anyways.

Aggressive flight times on a 450mah 3s battery are 3-4 minutes. It can carry bigger batteries, but then the joy of it being so nimble gets lost quickly. The key for such a small quad really is to keep it light. 4000-6000kV 1104 motors, 6-10A escs. Try to avoid steel screws and use aluminium ones instead.

The front and back parts fit around aluminium standoffs to keep the frame super stable. You can either tap the buzzer and receiver mounts or drill through and use nuts instead.

UPDATE!!! 6-2013
New Bukobot v2 and the brand new Bukito Portable Printer are out! Check it out at http://Deezmaker.com UPDATE!!!
All STL files are now being posted at bukobot.com Buko is my idea of a new framework for the next generation of RepRap 3D Printers. 3D printers using this framework are called Bukobots.
  • Easy to Build
  • Easy to Expand or Upgrade
  • Dual Extruder Option!
  • Great Documentation
  • Open Source
  • Environmentally Friendly
    • Keeping true to open source, I'll be uploading Bukobot parts here little by litte as they are tested and finalized.

Azteeg X1 Mount
  • This is the Board mount for the awesome Azteeg X1 board (http://www.panucatt.com/azteeg_X1_reprap_3d_printer_controller_p/ax13dp.htm) that the Bukobots will be using. The OpenSCAD file has some variables to adjust for other boards.
    • Buko Nameplate
  • These are the files I use to display the logo on the Bukobots
    • Z Coupler v1 & v2
    This is the coupler used for the Z threaded rods

If you are at all concerned about exposure to 3D printing fumes. These adapters can be used to connect 100mm clothes dryer ducting between your 3D printer and an outside window, with a switch block providing power to a small fan used to extract fumes.  
See instructions...

I used a 24v 40x40x10 mm brushless ball bearing fan on the enclosure end, which seems to provide sufficient airflow without effecting ABS prints. If you want something more powerful, a 40x40x20mm would also work. I cut a 45mm hole into the top of my enclosure, and mounted the fan on one side, and the duct adapter on the other using 4M x 16mm button head cap screws.  
On the window end I have a thick strip of scored and folded cardboard, which slots into a sliding window frame. This provides a reasonably air tight seal. The window side duct adapter sits inside the cardboard fold, which is taped together. The ducting is just pushed into the adapter - the steel loops jam it in place.  
The switch block has a 4 pin terminal with 1 pin removed, that I trimmed to match the fan connector. There is a STDP switch on one side and a 3mm jack on the other. Power s provided by a 24v power adapter.

NOW LIVE ON KICKSTARTER https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/1346069182/plexibots?ref=nav_search Compressed Air Engine
This is a six cylinder compressed air engine built using my pneumatic cylinders and rotary valves. I have not connected the output ports of the rotary valves to the ports of the cylinders using tubing (they would need to be connected).
In a gas powered engine, each cylinder is active or live only for half the cycle (down stroke). In this design each cylinder is active for the full cycle. Engine can be connected to a motor to generate power. Alternately, if the motor is powered, you should be able to use the engine as compressor.
One could potentially use this as a compressor at night using power off the grid when electricity rates are lower, and then as a generator during the day. Simpler two and four cylinder engines can also be constructed quite easily.
If you are looking for a cheap compressor to power the model, Harbor Freight Supply has one for $8 and it includes a pressure gauge!

title: Mazda Drip Moulding Cap, Part Number GJ6A505A1

description.text:
There probably isn't a whole lot of people who need this but I did, so I thought I'd share. This is a a replacement part for Mazda part number GJ6A505A1 (Cap, Drip Moulding) This is the little cap that covers the screw holes on the roofs of many late model Mazda vehicles. I lost the ones that came with my 2012 Mazda 5 after installing a roof rack, so I had to print some replacements. Four are required per vehicle. They slide into place with less effort than the originals, for easier removal later. The factory ones were pretty darn tight. One change to the STL that isn't reflected in the gallery photos is a little indented arrow to show the direction of removal. This isn't an exact replica of the OEM part, I modelled it based on pictures I found online, and measurements from the holes on my Mazda's roof. According to Jim Ellis Mazda Parts, the part should fit these cars:
Mazda CX-7 2010, 2011, 2012
Mazda CX-9 2010, 2011, 2012, 2013
Mazda Mazda 2 2011, 2012, 2013
Mazda Mazda 3 2004, 2005, 2006, 2007, 2008, 2009, 2010, 2011, 2012, 2013
Mazda Mazda 5 2006, 2007, 2008, 2009, 2010, 2012, 2013
Mazda Mazda 6 2014

Print with support and 100% infill. ABS or Nylon is probably your best bet as PLA will probably not hold in the sun.  
It's a bit tricky to remove support material without destroying the little wings (because I did indeed kinda mess them up), but some needle nose pliers, and an X-acto knife, and patience will do the trick.  
I printed in black ABS, and will probably spray them with some sort of paint to protect them from UV light and becoming brittle over time.

As a result of this activity, students should develop an understanding of:

i. design concepts
ii. teamwork needed in the design process
iii. impact of technology in manufacturing
iv. Students will explore design, construction, teamwork, and mechanical movement.

This Hand can be used with LEGO Mindstorms robot and is compatible with LEGO Technics pieces

The 3D printed parts were designed in Tinkercad.
CCSS

Build A Robotic Hand Participating teams of three or four students are provided with a bag of printed robotic hand parts, pins and springs. Each team must use the given materials to build a working robotic hand. The robotic hand must be able to pick up a small container such as an empty pill bottle. Teams of students must agree on the proper construction of the hand and identify what materials will be used. Students will draw a sketch of proper parts placement prior to construction. Resulting robotic hands will then be tested and checked for range of motion and successful completion of the given task. Special note should be made of the pistons and springs as this is the component that gives this "Hand" its variable grip. Unlike many other designs, this is not an "All or Nothing" approach to grabbing an object and maintaining a grip. This design gives some leeway as to the grip pressure and the movement range where an object can still be successfully secured and carried. Through this lesson, students will:
  • Learn design concepts.
  • Learn teamwork.
  • Learn problem solving techniques.
  • Learn about simple machines.

Instruct students to examine the materials provided and to work as a team to build a robotic hand out of the given materials. Provide students with the following parameters:
  • The robotic hand must be able to pick up and hold an empty pill bottle.
  • Teams of students must agree on the proper design for the robotic hand and identify what materials will be used.
  • Students should draw a sketch of proper parts placement prior to construction.
    • You should explain that teamwork, trial and error are part of the construction process. Questions for Students
  • Did you use all the materials provided to you? Why, or why not?
  • Which item was most critical to the robotic hand design?
  • How did working as a team help in the process?
  • Were there any drawbacks to working as a team relating to construction?
  • Name three industries that could make use of a robotic hand like this?

To prepare for this lesson you will need the following supplies:
  • Various printed appendage pieces
  • A few dozen connector pins
  • Small springs such as those found on ball point pens
2 - 60 minute periods

These reflective questions will help assess student understanding:
  • What was one thing you liked about your hand? What is its main weakness?
  • How can you change the attachment point to be compatible with other robots?
  • Are there algebraic and physical principles that can be applied to this activity?
  • How would you modify the design to create a better robotic hand?

• TryEngineering (www.tryengineering.org)
  • Design Your Own Robot (www.mos.org/robot/robot.html)
  • FIRST Robotics Competition (www.usfirst.org)
  • ITEA Standards for Technological Literacy: Content for the Study of Technology (www.iteaconnect.org/TAA)
  • NSTA National Science Education Standards (www.nsta.org/publications/nses.aspx)
  • NCTM Principles and Standards for School Mathematics (http://standards.nctm.org)
  • Robot Books (www.robotbooks.com)

title: LED automotive stop/indicator/tail lamp converter plate

description.text:
This is a mounting plate for circular European truck tail lights that include stop/indicator/tail. The plate allows for the original tungsten bulbs to be replaced with LEDs. I have these lights on my kit car and the upgrade has been fantastic - no more unseated bulbs!!

In addition to the light units you will need to buy pre-wired (with resistors) 4mm superbright LEDs (I bought 50 on Ebay) and 6 x 8mm LEDs for the tail lights. The 4mm LEDs needed little spring seats. I also bought a ballast resistor for each indicator to fool the relay into not increasing the blink rate (left standard the insufficient LED current draw makes the relay think a bulb has blown).

title: Le Voyage dans la Lune - A Trip to the Moon - Georges Méliès
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a model made after a drawing of my great great grandfather Georges Méliès.
The rocket in the eye of the moon is the most iconic image of his work, from the movie "le voyage dans la lune" (A trip to the moon).
You can find more info here :
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A_Trip_to_the_Moon
You can watch the movie here :
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UrHPyQGQ7vo

Be very carefull when removing the supports from the teardrop, it's pretty fragile.
I will try to make a V2 where the rocket and teardrop print as separate parts.

The model in the picture was printed a bit smaller than the provided stl (resize at will !) in white colorfab PLA at 0.06mm layers.

Like my stuff ? Follow me !
Love it ? Tip me ;)

License is non commercial. Want to sell my stuff ? Send me a message ;)

comments.text: Thank you for this wonderful model! I was fascinated by the moon from your grandfather’s film as a child. Some years ago a wall sculpture of the same character was briefly sold via catalog but I dallied and didn’t purchase one. I’ve regretted it since. I am starting to print your model. The wall sculpture from years ago has reappeared at Amazon.com but I find your model more faithful and prefer it. You must have so many characters for inspiration to pick from your grandfather’s films!

Cigar holder
Created with Fusion 360
PLA 1.75mm material
Sketchup of a soda can created in Fusion 360

This is a compilation of DesignByNumbers' ropelength minimising knots, arranged into a single file for the thin versions of the knots, and a single file for the thick versions. These are all of the prime knots with at most 7 crossings. Each knot is tied in a tube of constant radius, and pulled tight. In the thin version, the tube has been reduced to half-size in order to help you see the crossings. In the thick version, the tube appears at full scale. For more information about tight knots, see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ropelength.

author: Melog

description.text:
This is a model of the plastic piece that holds the 8mm nut in my Rola roof rack cross bar (Model 59834, APE series, not sure if the crossbars for other Rola racks use the same piece.)  
The cheap stainless bolts that came with the Rola roof rack had all kinds of burrs and it bound up on the nut during installation. This made removal very difficult and I ended up rounding out the hexagonal nut trap in the factory piece.

Printed in ABS at 50% infill, .2mm layer height. Not sure if it's as strong as the original (glass filled nylon), but seeing as how the originals rounded out pretty easily, I think the ABS print will work fine.  
Do not overtighten.

I printed it with 2 shells, no infill, no layers on top or bottom, .2mm layer height.

description.text:
6/06/2017 added left hinge, handle and handle ends .OBJ file for those that want to edit it and use thicker perspex.

Here is my take on the Lack Enclosure. I have used bits form other enclosures like the LEG JOINER and the Filament INTAKE TUBE so props to them.
Please bare in mind mine is not finished as i don't have a lot of time to build it.
It's made with 3 Ikea Lack tables this gives you just under a meter hight to work on your printer, and storage underneath( I will be putting perspex doors and sealing it too).
LED's for lighting, seals and filtered ventilation are still in the pipeline, I will update this as I go.

-----what you need-----
3mm screws
2mm wire (large paper clip)
magnetic strip
2mm perspex
3mm MDF board

----notes----

  • Print settings are in the pictures.(supports are only for the hinges everything should be printable as is.
  • You will need to cut grooves in to the perspex so you get a clean/ flush finish around the hinges and handles.
  • For left and right sides just print the mirror image along Y axis.
  • The hinges are held together with 2mm wire cut to length(large paper clip seen in picture)
  • The braces are screwed in with 3mm 12mm long wood screws.
  • The non- hinged gaps are 3mm thick so if you use board like me it needs to be 3mm but perspex will do to.
  • The hinge and handles are set for a 2mm thick perspex sheet, it's not to bad hardly flexes.
  • The lip of the handle is where you stick the magnetic strip that holds the doors shut firmly.
  • The handle is made of 3 parts the handle and handle parts x2 these are friction welded together.
  • To get extra hight to fit the printer in side i cut the fourth leg (that's not needed) in to 100mm tall sections (you can make them taller) then connected them to the base this is where you can use the LEG JOINER.
  • This is all made in mind that the PSU and Main Board will be located under the enclosure or behind.

description.text: My first attempt at a parametric object. The critical parameters that define a cycloid gear in this module are its circular pitch and number of teeth; the code then extrapolates other dimensions from there. As long as two gears have the same circular pitch they should mesh. Please exercise the object and post here if you find any bugs! Will also post revisions to this Gist at GitHub.

You'll need OpenSCAD in order to convert this script into a gear STL. The module you should concern yourself with is CycloidGear, it has a prototype like this: module CycloidGear(num_teeth, circ_pitch, base_circle_ratio, pinion_circle_ratio, h)
  • num_teeth is the number of teeth.
  • circ_pitch is the circular pitch, the length of an arc from the center of one tooth to the next, along the root circle. (The circumference of the root circle is num_teeth * circ_pitch.)
  • (optional) base_circle_ratio is the ratio of the base circle radius, the large circle the epicycle rolls around, to the root circular pitch. The default is to make it 6 times the length of the circular pitch.
  • (optional) pinion_circle_ratio is the ratio of the pinion circle radius, the small circle that rolls around the base circle, to the circular pitch. By default this circle's radius is equal to the circular pitch.
  • h is the height of the gear.
    • The gear is rendered with its origin at the origin of the context, with its rotational axis along the Z. Specifying a hole for an axle is not included in this module. Also available is a $precision global variable. This controls how many polygons are used to construct the the curves that form the tooth.
A model made by my friend Joel

The students design and print coasters with inspirational words.
During the activity the students learn new vocabulary, choose 4 different inspirational words and discuss the meaning of the words from their point of view. Why is the word inspirational for her? What does the word mean for him?.

This activity teaches a 3D printing"technique": using the exposed infill as a design feature.
Inspired by Structured Clock by Ysoft_be3D - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:557190

The concept of this lesson may be adapted to other topics and different ages.
For example:

  • Vocabulary such as family member names: each family member is written in each coaster.
  • Colors: each coaster is printed in a different color with the name of the color written on it.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

Different densities and patterns

Notes:

Print with no roof and floor.
Print with 6-10 shells.

I used Tinkercad:

  1. Create a cylinder 80mm diameter and 5 mm height
  2. With the text tool, write the inspirational word.
  3. Make the word as HOLE
  4. Align the word to the centre of the cylinder
  5. Group the cylinder and word.
  6. If the HOLE word created "separated islands" (for example, the letter O" makes a circular "island" when cut from the cylinder), make sure to connect the "islands" to the cylinder. This is to avoid the "islands" from being isolated from the rest of the model after taking the model off the build plate of the printer.

In MakerBot Desktop, Custom Settings/ Model Properties choose:
a. Number of Shells = 6 (to create a thick contour)
b. Roof Thickness = 0
c. Floor Thickness = 0

In Custom Settings/ Infill:
a. choose different infill percentage (15% to 20% recommended)
b. choose different infill patterns

View Preview to see the expected result before printing.

Background: Teaching abstract concepts in a foreign language can be challenging.
This activity promotes the learning of abstract concepts (inspirational words) in ESL (or any other foreign language class) through the design and printing of Inspirational Coasters. Overview: Students will be working in pairs to choose and create 4 inspirational coasters.
Students will create the coasters in TinkerCAD, adding a hollowed word to a flat cylinder. The cylinder will be printed exposing the infill (no roof and floor) as a design feature.

Duration of the lesson: 2 sessions of 45 minutes each.
  • First session:
    In this session the students work in pairs to choose inspirational words and design the coasters.

  • Choosing inspirational words:
    Each pair of students choose 4 inspirational words.
    If they don't know the English word for the word chosen, they can use a dictionary.

  • Designing the coasters:
    After choosing 4 word, the students use Tinkercad to design the coasters.
    Please reference to the section "How I designed this" above for instructions.
    • In MakerBot Desktop, the students choose different infill patterns and density and number of shells to create different designs.
    See the attached photos of coasters with different infill patterns and density. The students export their files and save them as ".makerbot" files (for MakerBot 5th get printers). Note: It is important to save the file ready to be printed (sliced). The ".stl" file does not contain the complete design.
    If your school printer is from a different brand, please use the correct slicer program and G-code file. Between sessions:
    Print all the students coasters and bring them to the next session.
  • Second Session: Showing the coasters and discussing the words and design
    • Class discussion:
    The students present their designs and explain:
    a. Why they chose the word?
    b. What the word means to them? Why it is inspirational?
    c. How they designed the coaster. This part expands the English vocabulary to words like density, percentage, infill, whole, empty, roof, floor, etc. Each student takes 2 coasters home. Moroccanstar Hexagonal Hexagonal catfill

• 3D printer
  • Tinkercad (computers with internet connection, Tinkercad accounts).
  • Makerbot Desktop software.

• Vocabulary
  • 3d printing
2 sessions of 45 minutes each.

author: leonardothecat

description.text:
Beyond the sheet-of-paper test, if your 3D printer bed is manually levelled it's nice to have a test print that lets you see how the first layer of lines is being deposited. This is a simple set of squares at the corners with circles within them that gives me a quick test of my MonoPrice Select Mini setup (12cm cubic print volume). It's also a good way to test for adhesion.

Sometimes straight lines appear to be working fine, but a curved or diagonal trace doesn't stick, reminding me to check the level, or to ensure my tape-plus-glue approach is up to par.

The pattern is 105 mm square. I recommend printing this with a 3mm brim for a good quick check.

Most often I never print this pattern for more than a few minutes, and have never let it run all the way through, 'cuz I see what I need to know pretty quickly, after the first layer is down. The circles are reassuring too - if they don't look round you may have an aspect ratio issue.

If you did let it print all the way through, it's only about 5grams of filament, so no big deal if you forget it and it runs through. If you do accidentally print the whole thing - share an "i made one" picture, I'd love to see how it looks. :)

Perhaps I'll add some additional features to it at some point, but for now, it's pretty useful as is.

title: iMac (21.5") Sign Holders with Signs - Ideal for School Computer Labs

description.text:
This attachment for 21.5" iMac computers is a great way to easily identify computers in a computer lab. The attachment rests snuggly on top of the iMac computer and has a slit in it for holding a name badge using thick paper or card stock. Placing a glue dot on the back of the iMac before placing this holder on the top will prevent the holder from moving around.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/k8m5AYteDqi

Google Slides Template for Customizing - link

As a classroom teacher working in a computer lab, I wanted to find a way to distinguish between the different computers in our lab. Traditionally, teachers may use stickers or numbers on the computers. I wanted to come up with a way that was easily changeable and fit the theme of our computer lab environment. I've included the latest version of the signs I'm using in my lab as well as the template in Google Slides form for you to edit and make your own.

Print Out the Default Signs To get started, print out the example PDF on thick card stock (+60 lbs). Print out two copies and then cut along the dark lines. Tape the signs back-to-back and they will fit snuggly in your printed sign holder. Customize Your Signs With Student Help As an activity, give students access to the Google Slideshow. Have students research their own inspirational figure. Students can then edit one of the slides to add a photo and brief overview of their figure. Printing out the document with 4 slides per page will give you a perfect size to cut and make your own. These signs can also just be printed out and taped to the front or back of the computer if you do not have iMacs of this size. Print Using Print Preview in Google Slides

PLA Filament
Scotch Tape
Thick Card Stock (+60 lbs.)
Printer

Specifically made for the Ultimaker but could be used anywhere. The normal hex driver you get has the handle at the same height as the top of the Ultimaker when adjusting the platfrom which makes it hard to get a straight angle on it and get the hot end close as well. This is long and thin which helps all of the above. The grip also slides up and down so that you can avoid putting weight on the platform while you are adjusting it.

You'll need a short 3mm screw and washer and a hex driver tip from a driver set. Optional 8mm X 5mm disk magnet.
Print the shaft with the big part down reasonably firm onto the platform.
If you clean the top of the shaft where the grip slides you need to keep the edges sharp so use a file on the flats and DON'T curl sand paper around it.
Press the tip from a nut driver set into the end of the shaft. Tight fit so you could heat it up first to help.
Print the gripper and use progressive bigger Allen keys to clean it out.
Keep adjusting till the gripper just slides nicely but careful not to go too far.
Stick the washer and screw on the top to keep the gripper in place.
Optionally press in an 8mm X 5mm disk magnet. I have removed mine as it was lifting the platform and it works better without it.
There are 25 notches in the gripper which equate to 0.02mm adjustment each.

author: LiorM

description.text: This repairs a common mode failure of the Replicator 2/2X. The X-axis cables on these printers regularly fail due to repeated bending caused by the forward and backward motion of the gantry. So instead of just replacing the stepper motor cable assembly and end stop cable assembly every time this happens, this repair replaces the length of cable that bends with a 0.5m RJ45 Cat-5 ethernet cable. This way if the replacement ethernet cable fails you just unclip it and insert another one - easy peasy - see instructions. Do a search for keystone rj45 on eBay to find these terminals. So far I have done 400 hours of printing with this repair - without incident =) The Alu-Carridge and Alu-X-Ends that you can see in the photos installed on my Repicator 2 are by Carl Raffle, and the Aluminium Z arms and HBP are by Bottleworks.

So first you need to purchase two Keystone Jack RJ45 terminals, along with a cheap krone tool.  
Before you do anything, remove the right side panel and fish out the x-cable assembly from above the right gantry. You will need to remove a few zip ties and slip the ribbon cables out from the cable retainers all the way down the right front pillar.  
Now the stepper ribbon cable should have a red pin alignment marker running down one side. However, the end-stop ribbon is completely black. So you need to get a paint marker and mark one side of it so you can align the pins later after you cut it.  
Next you need to find where your X-cable is broken - assuming it has failed. Either way, I would trim it 5-10mm back from where it sticks out the back of the gantry - which is where the failure point is most likely to be. Trim the other end at the top of the front right pillar. You should end up removing a section about 150-200mm long. Disconnect the terminals from the X end-stop and stepper motor.  
Now strip each end of the ribbon cables back 10mm and tin the ends with solder. Then use the krone tool to push them one by one into the RJ45 terminals. Be patient, they may take a few attempts to work their way down to the bottom. But each one should be firmly attached and flush with the bottom of the block. Make sure the two blocks are facing each other, and insert the leads in order so they mirror each other (using the pin alignment stripes). If you want to make sure - insert the Cat-5 cable and use a continuity tester on your volt meter to check that the pins all match up.  
Once pushed down, trim the excess tinned wires sticking out the sides of the terminal blocks, then press on the covers. Push in the end-stop and stepper motor terminals and attach that end's RJ45 block to the front of the gantry using zip ties (see photo).  
On the other RJ45 terminal, I installed an enclosure. I then used velcro tape to attached it to the inside of the right front pillar about half way up, replacing the ribbon cable inside the cable retainers.  
Finally, clip the 0.5m Cat-5 ethernet cable and fire up your printer.

comments.text: I'm sure I am doing something silly, but my x motor seems to be running in reverse.  At the start of a print, the extruder goes hard left (loudly) and gets stuck there.  I'm using standard 568B keystone jacks with a straight-through cat5 cable and continuity checks out.  1-1,2-2, etc.  From your pictures, it appears you have 1-4 on one wired to 5-8 on the other.  I'm not sure why that isn't 4 open circuits.

description.text:
Complete skirt for the Martian II quadcopter frame.

I've been using this for the past 4 weeks and it's been great for keeping the electronics protected from dirt and moisture, plus the camera angle hasn't slipped once.

It's been designed this specifically for my setup so your mileage may vary depending on your equipment, but if there's a simple modification you would like to accommodate your setup please ask and if it's a simple enough change I'll create another version for you.

It's designed for the standard 35mm x 5mm standoffs.

My setup is as follows:
I'm using a Foxeer XAT600M HS1177 FPV camera that measures 29mm from side to side which mounts via the small self tapping screws either side. (that measurement is from the flat part of the lugs rather than the actual body) It will flex a little in this area so should be able to accommodate slightly different sized cameras.
There is also a cu-out to allow for the power connectors of a Matek PDB. I've not tried it with the standard Martian/ Alien style PDB as I didn't want to use it due to the lack of a voltage regulator so can't comment on whether it would fit.

Measuring by eye, the minimum camera angle is roughly 10 degrees, maximum angle is roughly 50 degrees.
There are holes on the back to accept the antenna pigtail and also a Matek LCD and buzzer board.
Recesses on the top for battery straps in the middle and rear sections.
Recess on the RHS for the XT60 mount of a Matek PDB.

UPDATE 15th Apr 2017
Added some ribs to indicate camera angles of 0,10,20,30,40,50,60

UPDATE 31st Mar 2017
I've now uploaded a new version (Martian II Skirt 35mm version 2.stl) which has the pillar holes slightly increased in size from 5.5mm to 5.9mm, the previous version was a little tight in this regard and often required some finishing to get it to fit. This updated version just slides straight on.

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

0.2

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Needs supports touching the build plate.
Printed at 100% infill with single layer walls as the shell is only 1.2mm thick.
Print it rotated as you would mount it on the quadcopter - i.e. battery straps, camera and xtv antenna recess's at the top.

description.text:
I needed a tall tube to put my needle files in, it had to be over 150mm so is really pushing it for most 3D printers, so I decided to make a tube that would push into another tube with a lid.

So you have three pieces - the bottom with a bit that push-fits into the middle, the middle with a thread, and the lid which screws onto that thread, total internal height over about 150mm, but prints at about half that.

I made the hole in bottom/middle cylinders tapered (cones) so there is no sudden 90 degree edge which might have needed supports.

I split the STL into three files to make it easier to print however you like.

Very loosely based on pmoews pill containers and using the threads library.

Full sized printed in Hatchbox Neon Green PLA came out really well with 3 shells at 0.30mm/10% infill. Took under 6 hours to print.

I had to sand about 1mm off of the middle piece so the bottom would push-fit in, but I've fixed the model now.

description.text:
This is another case in point of why 3D printers are not just toys but rather tools.

This is a replica of my quick release mount for my Vivitar VPT-240 tripod. It's quite old so parts are expensive if not impossible to find. Hopefully this can help someone else. I'm using a 1/4"-20 3/4" long screw instead of the typical 1/4"-20 1/2" long one. I used a nut to replace the function of a washer as the screw is too long. My local hardware store was out of 1/2" screws. Nevertheless, it worked.

I was thinking of gluing a square sheet of cork to the surface to make the surface more suitable to receive a camera but it works just fine without it. It warped ever so slightly on one corner but it doesn't affect function.

Enjoy.

description.text:
Just a repaired model of this mount I wanted to build. Ran it through makeprintable.com

Edit 3/20/2017: So it seems the original model was scaled incorrectly, and there was a particular edge that was causing Simplify3D to carve a nasty hole, so I ended up throwing the model into TinkerCAD, fixing it a bit more, added some niceties like countersinks for the bolts, then re-scrubbing it with MakePrintable again.

I also have included a version customized to the print head I put together for my own Frankenbot.

title: Volvo 850 AC Damper Motor Control Testing

description.text: Since my old VOLVO 850 vehicle's AC panel is damaged, I don't have enough time / money/ knowledge to repair it. So I decide to replace it with Arduino and 3d printed panel. Video link https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=c2pUwXmcuro

First you need to find the VOLVO AC manual for pin definition. Google the keyword :Volvo 850 Auto AC Heater Systems (ECC) - Parts list:
1.L298N x 2
2.Arduino
3.... Using Arduino to read the damper motor position [0~5V], and driving the damper motor by using L298N (12V).
For future development, I also want to control AC compressor relay,
5 damper motor, and fan speed. Finally, I want to get all the temprature sensor value, and adding voice recognition chip for voice control , like : "warm", "cool", "more fan", "lower fan" ... At that time, I can completely throw away the AC panel ... great ! I can't wait...

I remixed this (or actually re-built it from the ground up) from MuninMoon's design. I wanted to actually stack two of these side by side, so I designed it with the screw holes hidden within the cable mount area. I also personally intend to use double-sided mounting tape to mount mine, but for those who want to use hardware, it is setup for that.

Also, I assumed that you would be using drywall or wood screws, so the mounting holes are tapered. if you need machine screws, you will need to go into the tinkercad design and fiddle with it (If I have time I will upload a second .stl file that is machine-screw compatible)

This simple thing extends the length (and comfort) of your thumbsticks allowing for faster accuracy and much more precise aim in mainly fps games. I had seen these kind of "thumbstick extenders." being praised on the internet but i was a bit cynical. Almost all the reviews where sponsored by the company making the product and i could not find any really negative ones. So i decided to try them out by designing my own. The way these work is they make the leverage of the stick itself almost 50% longer making it very light to move the sticks. They also allow for a larger range of motion enabling to use much higher sensitivity (I used to have a sensitivity of 40% in bf4, now i'm using 95% and i'm still much more accurate) There are two models, the PS4Cap which has the cross (in the pictures) for additional grip and a flat one. I highly recommend some kind of decal or pattern on the surface since PLA and ABS are both very slippery and don't give much grip naturally. If you have an Xbox One, PS3 or Xbox 360 and these don't fit please send me the measurements and i will make new models for them!

remixed_from.author: falconman
remixed_from.title: MP Select Mini Main Board Mount

description.text:
I am rebuilding my Monoprice Select Mini with the 4th Dimension Modification extended bed and extended height side panels. I have a Meanwell 150W (LRS-150-12) power supply inside the new extended height base. The extended height base intends you to use the stock bottom panel to mount the Printer Control board, but that strikes me as cantankerous, so I am leaving the bottom panel out.

Therefore, I needed a way to mount the main board without the stock bottom plate. I was not in the mood remove the components (power supply, C14 switch/jack, and SSR) in order to drill the base, so I made a bracket that can ziptie to the power supply.

My first version held the PCBA above the level of the top of the power supply. IT will fit there with the extended 4DM sides, but there's not much room left for fan airflow. So I redesigned the bracket to lower the PCBA down to the floor and renamed it "lowboy", like the trailers that carry heavy construction equipment that my son is interested in.

I used the PCBA tray from falconman, since I already had it printed out:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2139030

I just designed my part to be able to connect to his tray with zipties.

Two parts uploaded: standard and lowboy.
The standard holds the PCBA slightly above the top of the power supply.
The lowboy holds the PCBA lower so that the top of the PCBA is approximately level with the top of the power supply.

Native Solidworks, STEP, and STL files included.

I mounted the PCBA fan with the bracket made by vicviper:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1873905

title: Quick release camera clip/holster (work in progress)

description.text:
This is a work in progress for my dslr's and has not been world tested or weight tested. Use at your own risk.
Edit: { I have added file ReinforcedHolster that has Been beefed up I have not yet printed this one. I am working on a model that uses a metal spring from a cheap harbor freight spring clamp. If you print the Reinforced holster please upload a photo }
After working on the design I realized it would be good for a lot of things you want to lock in quickly. I am working on some variants for mounting to walls, car/truck trunks/cargo areas and blanks for you to drill holes to the size you want. I'm sure there is a better one out there but I preferred to use my time making one and learn from it then searching for one.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Steel

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

30

Notes:

Printed with abs, .3 nozzle, .15 first layer, .2 layers, .9 wall/top bottom thickness.
Supports used %6, zig zag, everywhere on the retainer clip. No supports used for clip fob. I've also updated the infill to %30.

My .3 nozzle printed this very well with these settings. I used supports for the spring clip and also the retaining flange overhang. You may be able to get away without but the cura supports removed easily for me so I would suggest using them.

Again this is not world or weight tested. I am thinking of making the retainer flanges thicker and also adding some other features so stay tuned or update yourself, I'd love to see other ideas about the design.

I used paracord for the fob and a knot to secure it in the fob. With standard paracord the knot is slightly too big for the button cover to be used. I know there are thinner and stronger cords so use what works that's strong enough.

The belt loop holes are just under 40mm long and 6mm wide which fits my 35mm wide 3mm thick leather belt snugly. If enough people need it larger or a different size I'll include it in the next remix. I'm also going to make one to fit my camera bag strap so I may just include it in the remix files.

I have also printed this about %20 smaller for holding grocery bags in the trunk. I used braided mason line for the smaller one, which is strong and it loops thru the bags easily .

This is a work-in-progress case for the great ESP32 Thing from Sparkfun. I love this board: it has everything for development and testing of the ESP32.

This is my first 3D design, so it comes with quite some room for improvements:

  • my board is currently header-less. I provisioned some room for headers below the board, but it would need another cover
  • speaking about the cover, some holes for LED/headers/buttons would be great, but would make it either very big, or fragile...
  • the box is a little bit too tight, it was difficult to insert the board, and would be even more to remove it
  • the small part between USB and battery connectors is to thin, and broke right away; I should remove it

title: Ruger MK III / IV 22/45 +1 Magazine Extension

description.text:
Building off my Ruger Mark IV 22/45 Magazine Base Pad, here's a +1 mag extension. It allows the follower to drop down a little further letting you squeeze in that 11th round. This +1 extension will work with both the Mark III and the Mark IV 22/45.

I'm having some trouble printing this, as when I print on my MP Select Mini, the angle on the front is too steep. When I try to print with support, the supports stick to the PLA and it looks like crap. So, I'm printing it without support and sanding down the roughness. If anyone has any idea how to print this better, please leave a comment and let me know.

Proof that it holds 11 rounds! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O2to-Q7a3Pw

EDIT: I've added a version 2 to this design. The slope from the front of the piece to the bottom is less severe, so it should print a hell of a lot easier and come out looking better. It doesn't even show up red in Cura anymore.

comments.text: Great design! Works great. Any chance you would create a MKIII extended base plate?
comments.author: ductape

comments.text: It'll work on the MKIII too. The magazine you see in the pics is actually an MKIII mag.
comments.author: ductape

comments.text: Sorry I should have been more clear. Standard MKIII not the 22/45 version.
comments.author: rezin8

comments.text: I don't have a MKIII around to model from, so sorry. I'll see if I can borrow one from one of my friends and see what I can do.
comments.author: ductape

comments.text: Works fine, holds 11 shells. I think you could reduce the thickness of the design a 'little' and still be ok as it holds about 11 1/2 shells. The hole in the bottom is also a little bigger and allows the pin to poke out a little more than the original. You may be able to see this in the pictures of my make. Both of these are no big deal. Shells fed fine just cycling the action but I haven't taken it to the range yet. I printed in 30% infill and they seem strong enough at least for now.  If you don't use 100% infill you may want to add extra top, bottom, and side layers.
comments.author: Tripplett

comments.text: So, I took your feedback and went and made some changes. I've uploaded that file, what I've termed "shorty" for some weird reason. The overall height is 2.5mm shorter, and I shortened the through hole up another 0.5mm, which takes a total of 3mm out of the spring length once put together. I've printed one out and it works great. If you don't mind, try one out for yourself and let me know what you think.
comments.author: Tripplett

comments.text: I just finished printing a 'shorty'.  I like it much better.  Just enough excess to load 11 shells easily without wasted space.  Nice work.  I'll have to print your charging handle now too.
comments.author: rezin8

comments.text: It took a little work to get that length just right. Too bad Fusion 360 doesn't model springs yet, otherwise I would have just modeled the whole magazine and worked on it until the spring compressed the correct length rather than having to adjust, print, adjust some more, print, and hope for the best. Luckily it only took me 2 more tries to get it right. Glad you like the new version!
comments.author: Tripplett

comments.text: You should try printing it with the front angle flat on the bed, so the mating channel is closer to 45deg relative to the bed.
comments.author: Landru

comments.text: The mating channel prints just fine. In fact, everything prints just fine except the front angle. If I were to put it flat on the bed, then it would be fine and everything else would be screwed up.
comments.author: Landru

I didn't found Extruder temperature column for ABS. "After slicing this 10cm high column change the extruder temperature in the GCODE file after 10mm travel in the Z axis. Examine the print and determine the best extruder temperature for the filament you are currently using. The printed columns can be stored and used as reminders if the same filament is used in the future." Simply add:
M104 S240 ; for example set temperature 240'C
Before G1 Zxx command in G-CODE file. PLA version http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:217793

title: Wanhao Duplicator I3 Bowden Extruder for E3D V6  ReFresh

description.text:
I used a current design as inspiration for this. Since I started drawing from scratch I'm calling it refresh instead of a remix. I added a second hole for the fan to help hold it in place. Holes for the cable chain. I made the end-stop brackets a little thicker to be more durable. the tube for the print cooler has been modified to compress the air a little more. the spacing for the X belt have been corrected so that you can use any of the tensioners for the V2.1printers there are holes on the side for mounting a bracket for the BL Touch with a slot in the back to run the wires through so you can mount it with the logo facing out.

the design that inspired this is found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1777358

Printer:

modified Wanhao I3, Ramp 1.4, E3dV6 Titian extruder

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.25 is fine

Infill:

18-25%

Notes:

I used PETG for its toughness. I was able to print w/o supports. my bridging setting are Unsupported area threshold 5.0, extra inflation distance 2.0, bridging extrusion multiplier 120%, Bridging speed multiplier 170%

I recommend 3 outer shells and 3-4 top and bottom layers, use what ever infill pattern you r used to using.

the little cylinder to the side is to help keep the offset for the fan for being printed too quickly.it distorted before I added it for some reason.

I used the latest E3D V6 as my model and left the rings for holding it on the tight side so you can sand for a perfect fit. it won't take very much if any. if it is loose sand the flats of the clamping block evenly so that you can tighten it down more.

the holes for nut to secure the 3mm clamping block are a good fit but you may need to use a small flat blade screw driver to keep it from spinning. it was a trade off of a really tight fit and not being able to ever remove it, or a looser fit where you could if needed. IE it striped threads.

also recommend that you add a filament filter if you don't already have one. I have been using a few drops of olive oil on a sponge as a lubricant.

This is an extended receiver box designed for the Traxxas Summit/E-revo. Tested and fit perfectly with a 42mm bl motor and 14 tooth pinion. May not fit with 775 titan motor, i cannot test it. If it doesn't, then the mounting holes have to be moved few millimeters inner.

INFO:

As for the cover, there are 2 versions: one with a Traxxas logo implemented and one without it. The one with the logo is 0.25mm thicker, this is why i recommend 0.25mm as layer hight. And also, all the flat panels are 1mm thick so 0.25mm would be 4 layers, so it should be strong enough.

The cover is designed to be watertight, thus it should be a tight fit. Depending on your printer, you might need to file off some of the sides of the box to make it fit nicely.

You'll need 6 pc of M3x6mm button head screw for this box. 2 screws need to mount the box to the chassis stock mounting points, and 4 screws to secure the top cover. The mounting points of the top cover is about 6mm deep, so keep this in mind.

Printing info:
Layer: 0.25mm
infill: 100%
since it does not have curvy objects(except the trx logo) you can print it faster than usual, to save some printing time. 60-70mm/s should be fine. Print it flat side down, and wait with the removal until the objects are completely cooled down, otherwise the thin plates can be deformed during the removal.

UPDATE: Just uploaded the v2 version. Changes: relocated the mounting holes to the chassis. added 0.1mm tolerance to the cover, and also added 0.25mm additional wall thickness to the sidewalls, bottom, and cover. And made a "cutoff" next to the motor mount for some additional clearance for the wires. And the most important: added 1 cm hight for the sidewalls, to be able to fit more gadgets inside. My BEC and receiver did not fit the v1, but it does fit the v2.

Notes:The v2 version is backward compatible, but a v1 cover will not fit a v2 box.
Be careful with the cover, because the L shaped lip have a tendency to brake down if the wires are too tight. Might reinforce it in the future, or create a whole new design for his part.

Feel free to comment, and suggest if you have any ideas.

This is a tray to hold 2 dial test indicators and a space to hold accessories like different points. Should work with most test indicators that toolmakers use. The stl file is of the part on the left. After printing the first part it was clear the finger cutouts were too small. Also, I cored out some of the material from the back (not visible).

description.text:
This is a remake of Hiroko Price's funnel (kitahiro921). Her design is great, but seemed just a bit fragile to me. Besides, I wanted to learn how to design something like this in FreeCAD, so I created my own version. The wall thickness on this one is around 1.2 mm, a very small increase over the original but enough to make it a bit stronger (on my printer, anyway). I also added a small lip to the top to make that edge a little bit more robust.

Thank you so much Hiroko for the original design, and for allowing me to post my version of it. Also thanks to Duncan Gunn (DigitalDunc) for posting the FreeCAD file for his Offset Funnel. You inspired me to post the source file for my designs as well.

author: dwtaylor

title: 100th remix for Hypercube X carriage with LM8LUUs

description.text:
I have modified the X carriage. I wanted to use LM8LUUs and have full bearing holders. And obviously this means the X axis is using 8mm rod. I have increased the strength and amount of plastic in many areas on the carriage. Especially the belt attachment points. Another change I made was to customize this for my particular endstop. A picture of the endstop is included. I prefer these endstops, as they are dirt cheap and they are smaller than what Tech2C originally used. They are available on ebay and aliexpress.

You have to mod the endstop slightly. Use a drill and drill the screw mounting holes slightly larger to 3mm. If you don't have metric bits, find the closest oversize standard.

The x carriage also has a hole to route the endstop wires thru as seen in the picture.

Use however you like. Original Sketchup files included for you use.

comments.text: Note to self (and others).  Install the switch before you put the belts on, waaaay easier that way.

title: Prusa i3 MK2/S/3 LED Panel Light ClipOn Upgrade

description.text:
eBay has some great cheap 12V 4W LED panels for car interior lights (Search: 48 SMD COB Panel LED T10 Car 12V) - Why not make a couple of lamps for my Prusa 3D printer?

I decided to make a design based on the earlier designed ClipOn system for the main Prusa frame.
As the LED panel get very hot when used directly on 12V, there have to be a good ventilation grid for cooling.

Design challenge:

  • All plastic and easy to print (no screws, etc...)
  • As few parts as possible
  • Little to no post-processing of finished printed parts (edges, holes, etc.)
  • Wires should be integrated in the solution
  • Light should be adjustable (direction)

If you like this design, you may also like:

  • Prusa i3 MK2/S/3 Filament Guide ClipOn
  • Prusa i3 MK2/S/3 Filament Spool Holder ClipOn

Note for MK3: MK3 uses 24V, therefore you have to use LED panels for 24V or connect two lamps with 12V LED panels in series.

Please show your great makings of this thing, leave a comment and/or a tip :-)

Printer:

Original Prusa i3 MK2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.20mm

Infill:

25% Rectlinear

Notes:

3 top an bottom layers, 2 perimeters. 0.4mm default tip.

As the lamp get hot, ABS or PETG is best suited materials. I used ABS.

Assembly

See photos for assembly.

  • Optionally: If ABS vapor smooth parts.

  • Mount LED panel with the double sided tape.
  • Guide wires through the parts (may need to extend/replace wire).
  • Snap the two parts together.

  • Click on Prusa frame.

  • Optionally: Secure wire with a ziptie using the channel below back hole.

  • Connect to 12V power.

title: WanHao Duplicator I3 2.1 and Plus Belt Tensioner

description.text:
To install this on a DI3 PLUS you must disassemble your extruder and rotate the stepper motor so that the plug faces the print bed. See pictures for orientation of plug.

^ That part isn't hard. Something like 3 screws to take off and 5 minutes worth of rejiggering.

Modified this belt tensioner to work on the DI3 Plus.

The belts do not rub or cause issues at either extreme.

Installation:

To attach the body you'll need two M4 x 12mm screws and two M4 flat washers.

You have to screw them into the same place as the stock X axis belt screws go. The holes in my machine were not threaded all the way through, but by using a bit of force I managed to thread the screws straight through the plate - so basically, if your screws seem to be bottoming out/too long, keep turning till they start creating their own threads and go through the gantry plate.

I think the knob requires an M3 x 25mm mm screw and an M3 hexnut to mount.

I modified the original STL (this is a remix) in Solidworks, and provided that file in case it's of use to anyone.

Enjoy!

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

40% minimum

Notes:

Print it orientated so that flat side with the hexagon and two oval holes is on the print bed.

No supports needed.

This is intended for use with mounting or double sided tape on the flat side (The clip is 25mm wide, a tape of the same width would be easiest), it is approximately 10mm in diameter when not clipped.

I used this to hold small wire loom. I have not tried scaling up it's diameter yet, but the lock will probably get pretty clunky at larger sizes. For my purpose ABS made the most sense, therefore as of now I'm unsure if PLA will be able to handle the flexing when locking it on the third tooth.

Doesn't Matter

Doesn't Matter

This is a dust collector for a CarveWright CNC carver. I've seen others for sale, but for such a simple design, have seen nothing similar on Thingiverse. I decided to put this design out there for others to improve their CarveWright experience without yet another additional purchase. This design works for me and removes 90% of the airborne dust during carving and keeps my machine cleaner with less vacuuming and blowing in between projects. The hose adapter is tapered to fit an 1-1/4" small shop vac.
The 4 pieces will need to be bonded together. I use a good quality thick cyanoacrylate (super glue) adhesive to bond my pieces together. I recommend 2P-10 brand with accelerator and use these on many of my 3D prints.
Please note, my machine which this works perfectly for, is an N01 model from 2007. I do not know if the later (or earlier) machines work with this design. Check the overall opening width, thickness at bottom and top and modify the stl files as necessary.
You WILL need to trim the clear plastic cover shield back a bit to get this attachment to fit - this is common for all aftermarket dust collectors. There are limit switches mounted at the top of the shield which you can can hear "tik" when you raise and lower the shield. I cut mine below the "tik" and 1/8" above flush with the side metal edges. Do your research before you cut the shield and understand this will void any current warranty you may have with CarveWright.
